comments.commentBody: How about John Bolton? http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2011/03/26/us/AP-US-Republicans-Iowa-Bol.... He claims President Obama is not fit to be President based on just - Libya handling!?! I say Make John Bolton President for One day and he will know it is the hardest job on earth. If John Bolton has a problem he should be talking to UN Ambassador Suasan Rice and Secretary Clinton and DOD Robert Gates for their roles in Libya. They were the ones on the ground reporting to President Obama. How is he qualified to say President Obama did not handle it well, when we all know how badly President Bush-John Bolton mishandled Iraq!! Look who is talking. Crazy.

Was there ever a bigger bunch of apologists, whiners, and petty, shallow thinkers than the current crop of Republican "presidential candidates"?   Demint is the smartest of the bunch, that is, smart enough to see the writing on the wall.  Scott Brown came out in favor of Planned Parenthood and was stoned for blasphemy.  We are seeing the "Sovietization" of the GOP and it is sad, sad, sad.
I hope that was a wink and a nod at Allen West.

This address is at least a week too late.

I'd like a coherent explanation of why we're attacking Libya, but allowing other mideast thugs to fire onto protesters.

As a moderate who leans to the right, I believe that there is an opportunity for a unknown candidate who uses his or her common sense during the campaign. If the Republicans turn this election into a battle of social commentary, they will lose. If the Democrats and their leader, President Obama, do not find some success from his first (and, possibly only) term, the Republicans could have a field day. If a candidate appears from any party who can appear to be a moderate in regards to social issues, he or she will have a huge advantage. The idea that the economy, the wars, and the enviroment will be of less importance is ludicrous! If you look at previous elections, it is usually the candidate who leans towards the moderate and concillatory platform that does well. We in the United States, generally, do not take well to candidates who are far to the left, far to the right, or simply....far from reality. Mr. Obama promised "Change" in Washington, the United States, and the world....and he has failed. It is business as usual. Go ahead candidates....hire your high priced consultants! Spend the millions of campaign dollars! Your wasting your  resources. All you need to do is ask me the route to take and you'll be golden!

"...if House Majority Speaker Boehner delivers on his promise to create jobs... the Republicans would win in a cakewalk"
@ shadowmagiciar: if by some miracle the unemployment rate declines, it will be of political benefit to the president. Presidential elections are invariably a referendum on the economy.

It's good to see the GOP returning back to the real issues that challenge our country: School prayer. The Pledge of Allegiance. Sexual preference. Evolution. Sex education. Human reproduction.

A political party with a platform of (a) social Darwinism and (2) defunding all government functions except police, prisons, and the military.

God help us all.

Ah yes, Iowa. This is the state where on Monday, February 7th of this year Frank Luntz had one of his GOP focus groups, this time with caucus voters. Televised live by Fox News that evening, a woman stated, "I believe that he (Obama) is a Muslim." Luntz then asked the rest of the group how many believed Obama is Muslim. About half the group raised their hands (out of approximately 25 people).

Luntz then tried to give the group a way out. “Now do you understand the implications of what you’re saying here?” Luntz asked. “What the media’s going to say about this group and about the Iowa Caucus voters in the future. Do you realize what you’re opening up here?”

No one demurred.

Another person said, "His religious belief is liberalism and, you know, that's the most intolerant religion of all. There's no room for wiggle in that..."

Still another participant said, "I do think it is quite possible he (Obama) is Muslim even though he says he is Christian..."

This, in a nutshell, is your GOP/Tea Party voter in a good deal of the country: factually wrong and logically challenged.
None of the folks mentioned in this piece has a chance.  The only candidate who does is Mitch Daniels.  If Daniels doesn't run, it's over before it began.
So far I haven't seen any Republican politician propose anything besides idolatry to create jobs.

I don't know why these toadies are so reluctant to put their own names on their program given the obvious inability of America the Stupid to put the blame on them for any of their vandalism over the past 35 years.

Praise Governor Christie?
FOr what? I know the hype-Christie is a man of principle-he is a man of action. So other than give a ton of money back tot he wealthiest and the Corporations what is it he has done. New Jersey has 200,000 millionaires. and it has 110,000 teachers. So the teachers get salary cuts and bigger classrooms for what reason? And the Millionaires get a raise-for what reason?

I suggest that those of you who back the Republicans stop believing what you hear and start believing what you actually see. I have heard Actions speak louder than words. Except in the Republican Party. Where hype and party allegiance is the only thing that matters.

I hope that Mr De Mint gets South Carolina to secede. But a better idea - they would not need to secede if we just told SC to get out.

jb--Thanks for the clarification.  It still seems to me that you're painting with too broad a brush. There are cases in which privatization makes sense, and other cases in which it doesn't.  Perhaps the test for whether a function should be performed in the public or private sector is whether that function will be better performed with competition or not.  When it comes to fire departments, probably not.  When it comes to education, though, it may well be that you get better performance when schools can't take a captive audience for granted.

Fareed Zakaria GPS on CNN
What's up, NYT? Why do I always have to remind you of this? He's the best of the Sunday shows and you know it.
Can I become a contributor?
Republicans do not represent me whatsoever. They love corporations, and hate people. No more of them and their repulsive, empty values, please!

One reason Iowans can focus on values is because they are doing really, really well economically. Corn and soybean prices are soaring and the price of farm land is skyrocketing.Trolling on the values trail in Iowa will put Republicans sorely out of touch even with their Republican supporters elsewhere in the country.

I love watching Republicans implode; this kind of stuff only helps.

While Obama and Clinton cheer on the civil unrest and rebellions across the middle east, and even assist it in the case of Libya, they proceed on the assumption that what evoles from these countries will in fact be more "democratic". We can only hope they are correct to be so optimistic; anything less would certainly be cause for consternation in the west. Even a few years of tumoil in this region of the world does not work in our national interest.

There is a connect between the lack of a coherent foriegn policy by this administration and the actions, to date, of conflicting statements by Obama and Hillary, unknown goals, unatributted leadership of the military effort in Libya, and the initiation of this venture without congressional consultation. Not to mention the expense to the taxpayer.

Chicklet 49:  It is obvious that you sit there comfortably smug in Douglastown never having to worry about job security. Yet there are millions who have because of the horrendous mismanagement and greed by your fellow republicans over the previous eight years. Enough republicans actually had some compassion (or they were scared of the consequences) and they voted with the democrats for several extensions of unemployment compensation. And contrary to your careless statement these do not go on for ever. Furthermore, none of the republican presidential hopefuls, declared or otherwise, has yet to give even a remote hint of a useful idea on how to resuscitate the country economically, let alone implement it as president. They try to emulate the Tea Party idea of small government through blind cutbacks, even those of programs like basic research, innovation and competitiveness initiatives, and education, programs that have accounted for over half the wealth generated in the US over the last 60 years. Cutbacks under the mantra of everybody must share in the sacrifice- except of course the mostly republican wealthy- they get tax relieve, which they invests in corporations, such as GE that don't pay any taxes- even claim billions in tax credit. And guess who initiated these corporate welfare programs? No less than the great idol of the Republican Party. And by the way, see how well austerity programs work in the UK, Spain and Ireland, so well that their economies have yet get traction. Yes, with such outstanding candidates as the present presidential wannabes, if anyone of them is elected, it will be back to the future of the 19th century.

And agricultural government subsidies. Even in Iowa there's a desire for Government if it is in their interest. Keep those Agricultural Subsidies coming and increase them, please. They are at least polite people, if hypocrites too.

Misdirection, for professional pickpockets, and the GOP alike, is a perennial favorite used to facilitate the best stealing.

Somebody is hardly going to notice their wallet being pilfered if they are in the midst of being punched in the face.
How in the world can Newt Gingrich be a values candidate with his marital background. It is simply hypocritical. Is he counting on voter amnesia?

Friday's game was a sad excuse of entertainment.No defense,no scheme,only a kind of pinball in a court.Billups lost in a limbo,Amar'e,Anthony and most of the players without common sense to know when and where to shoot the ball or do a half-court job,and a clueless coach ,that only became aware of Jennings,and his 3-ponters, after the end of first period.
After that i watched Ohio State X Kentucky to clean myself of the foul mood.I'm doing my best to believe in The Knicks,but it's so difficult with the \"Three Stooges\" ( Dolan,Thomas and D'Antoni ) behind the scenes.
I guess the only way to enjoy a good game is watching Thunder,Bulls,Sixers and Lakers and the NCAA Elite 8 games.

This trade was terrible. First of all I would not have let Felton go for an aging Chauncey Billups, he cannot guard anyone anymore. The two Amare and Carmelo have and probably will never be great defenders. Not looking good for the Knicks
